sentences.sentence: The equation of climate policy with colonialism - suggested by Tanveer Ahmed in "Climate change activism is the new 'white man's burden' " (March 6) - is frankly ridiculous.The armed invasion of a country is certainly not comparable to the legitimate choice of a party choosing not to undertake a transaction (the sale of coal).Besides that, in his opinion piece we find another cost-benefit analysis in which only costs are discussed.

He makes no mention of the economic and social disruption that climate change is projected to cause, especially in the equatorial and tropical countries under his consideration.Ching AngKensington Gardens, SACoal is no saviour for developing nations"The white man's burden" inferred by psychiatrist Tanveer Ahmed is an insult to our neighbours.

He's thinking in the style of two centuries ago suggesting we should bring more coal to bear in these growing nations, as if it would benefit them rather than our bottom line.He worries about "moral leadership" yet talks of not "depriving the poorest of the coal" he thinks "they demand".Coal is no saviour, nor even a friend of the people in the Philippines or Vietnam.

That burden brings all sorts of pollution and health issues besides global warming, of which these people of the tropics, of all people, have most to fear.And despite the subsidies we afford it, coal is now proven to be more expensive than new renewable energy with storage options.

We do more to help these countries by keeping our coal in the ground, not by trying to make a quick buck flogging it cheaply to them.If anything, we have a moral duty to ensure access to the best energy solutions for the 21st century, and last but not least a liveable climate for the hundreds of millions to our north who live closer to the edge on climate than ourselves.Tom HuntOak Flats, NSWGas v coal assertions too much hot airKevin Gallagher's opinion piece ("Exporting gas and storing CO2 is pathway to greener future", March 6) simply repeats the discredited assertion that Australia is helping to slow climate change by exporting gas.First, there is little convincing evidence that the gas we export is replacing the burning of coal rather than adding to it.

Second, even if the gas were to replace coal, the greenhouse gases released when the gas is burned are supplemented by those involved in producing, compressing and transporting the gas as well as the contribution from fugitive emissions.When the complete picture of our LPG exports is assessed, it would not be helping the problem even if it did replace coal.Mr Gallagher is, of course, very well paid by Santos to try to portray their export of gas as morally defensible, but the facts show that it is simply a cynical commercial exercise.Professor Ian LoweMarcoola, QldDon't ignore the admirable ARENAEnergy Minister Angus Taylor's technology road map is a distraction from the challenge of anthropogenic climate change and a refusal to invest in the clean energy solutions that already exist.Nowhere in the road map does Taylor mention ARENA, Australia's leading renewable energy agency with a proven track record for getting things done.It ignores our community's desire for sustainable jobs, cheaper power bills, and clean energy.
The technology already exists to reduce emissions and power bills, the technology can expanded and deployed at a much faster rate with increased investment.
ARENA is the agency that had the resources to do this.However, ARENA's current funding is likely to run out by the end of 2020 unless its refunded.
To continue its important work, it needs $2.5 billion.That means no new projects, no new developments, no new technological research.

No clean solutions to the climate crisis.Joseph ZagariNorth Willoughby, NSWGet mean on DeanMay I add my support to Ramani Venkatramani ("Done with Dean", Letters, March 5).As a longtime subscriber and AFR Leaders Panelist, I read the Fin for its qualify journalism and high-class satire.
Think the late great Peter Ruehl or dear old Pierpont!

Rowan Dean, by comparison, barely makes the grade.To cease running Joe Aston's wonderful "The Adventures of..." while continuing to publish Dean's weak humour is an editorial travesty which perhaps only a groundswell of readers' letters will rectify?Kerry M. BellJandakot, WARethink needed on holiday pay loadingI have never been able to understand why employees should receive 17.5 per cent more pay when they are on holiday.
I would like to suggest that the leave loading be removed and the money saved be transferred to the employee's superannuation account.
The 17.5 per cent leave loading is equivalent to a 1.35 per cent superannuation contribution.

The advantages are that it costs nothing, it simplifies the award structure and the employee will end up with a far better retirement fund.David CahillNorthwood, NSWInside the education Ponzi schemeJosh Roskam is on the money in relation to our university sector's propensity to privatise gains and socialise losses ("Don't bail out bloated unis", March 6), but he got one thing wrong.

They are not just certificate factories - they are in fact a de facto form of permanent residence.Retired professors I know have all commented on the relentless pressure to pass substandard foreign students to keep the grotesque education-migration Ponzi scheme going.All sides of politics are in on this scam for their own bankrupt reasons.

While there are pockets of excellence, the average output of our universities is so bad I know of some employers who require graduates to sit knowledge tests to sift out the frauds even in subjects like electrical engineering.My all-time favourite is a foreign student with an honours degree in electrical engineering going for a $100,000 job who was asked by the business owner to perform a trade level task of putting a battery pack in a cordless drill and screwing something to a board, but could not work out how to do it in the time allowed.

We have passed the point of no return.Peter HaggstromBondi Beach, NSWThe waylaying of service to the publicJames Whelan and the Centre for Policy Development urge the Australian Public Service to serve the government of the day with integrity and provide "frank and fearless advice" on questions of public policy, from national security to fiscal policy to social security, across multiple jurisdictions ("Can the public service save itself?
", March 5).The APS is supposed to deliver "cradle to grave" services to the community.

The Australian National Dictionary Centre defines a public servant as "someone who labours for the public good".The inveterate defence of Scott Morrison's electoral-gain-driven sports grant rort by Philip Gaetjens, head of the PMO, is the antithesis of community service.
Australia's top bureaucrat is intent on serving his master despite eroding community trust and goodwill.
Self-interested leadership, aka "feathering one's nest", risks becoming the APS catch-cry.
Regardless of top-down or middle-management formulation, policy that preserves or enhances societal good has been waylaid by Gaetjen's poor leadership.Joseph TingCarina, Qld

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
